Award.AwardTitle: WiFiUS: Ubiquitous Video over Dynamic Spectrum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Mobile phones and tablets are the most widely-used wireless communication devices nowadays. Video already represents the majority of mobile traffic and is expected to grow significantly in the coming years. Network operators are already facing shortage of bandwidth to support such a huge amount of traffic, despite the availability of newer cellular communication technologies. A solution to increase the availability and the efficiency of wireless communication technologies is given by cognitive radio networks (CRNs). Enabled by adaptive communication protocols, CRNs have the capability to sense a wide range of the spectrum and the agility to make use of the available resources dynamically. Accordingly, they can reclaim unused spectrum (i.e., whitespace) for wireless communications while avoiding interferences with between licensed and unlicensed users. However, video delivery over CRNs presents several challenges related to the highly-varying nature of the channel, the presence of misbehaving users, and the dynamic availability of heterogeneous resources.

This project addresses such challenges and makes CRNs suitable as a platform to provide ubiquitous wireless video. The research takes a flexible approach that is applicable to diverse regulations across national boundaries and specifically targets mobile devices. It helps create a cognitive phone, i.e., a smartphone with cognitive radio capabilities, to bridge the gap between the technologies behind CRNs and real applications. The project builds on two major research thrusts. First, it adopts spectrum crowd-sensing as a means to model the availability of whitespace at multiple scales and support long-lived communications. Such an approach enables novel solutions to accurately characterize the channel and enforce the policies established by the communication authorities. Second, it leverages adaptive mechanisms as foundations to efficiently deliver video streams to end users. These mechanisms are implemented through streaming protocols and components in the network infrastructure that provide video content with a target quality of experience. The project also integrates synergistic activities between the United States and Finland in education, industry collaboration, and entrepreneurship.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the emergence of IoT paradigm that can connect numerous heterogenous devices and systems together, it is envisioned that future-generation networks will consists of systems of interdependent networks and systems, such as wireless sensor networks, cellular networks, and sociotechnical networks. As a result, novel heterogeneous network/architectural designs are highly needed to enhance the efficiency of wireless spectrum usage and ensure efficient data fusion, fair resource allocation, high QoS, and fault-tolerance. Thus, we investigated the design and development of new network/architectural (e.g., fog computing-based) designs and developed techniques for cooperative or coordinated communication, accurate synchronization methods, and distributed computing/streaming. The specific research studies can be summarized as follows.

Video in whitespace and whitespace offloading: We studied the characteristics of whitespace channel as a Tier-3 user, characterize the collective effect of the two factors below as experienced by a Tier-3 client and study its effect on bandwidth demanding applications like video streaming: (1) the hierarchy in accessing the channel calls for superior adaptation of Tier-3 devices with varying spectral opportunity (2) the frequency of arrival of Tier-2 users will force Tier-3 networks to adapt, often at a much smaller timescale than experienced in the current channelized mode of access. Using SVC, we designed an MDP based adaptive video streaming algorithm for the highly dynamic whitespace channel. We studied how to efficiently use the whitespace channel to reduce the data load in cellular network ? whitespace offloading. 

AMUSE offloading: Wireless Internet service providers (ISPs) are increasingly changing their pricing plans and deploying Wi-Fi hotspots to offload their mobile traffic to cope with the exponential increase in demand of mobile data. Thus, users face a complex, multi-dimensional tradeoff between cost, throughput, and delay in making their offloading decisions: while they may save money and receive a higher throughput by waiting for Wi-Fi access, they may not wait for Wi-Fi if they are sensitive to delay. To navigate this tradeoff, we developed Adaptive bandwidth Management through USer-Empowerment (AMUSE), a functional prototype of a practical, cost-aware Wi-Fi offloading system that takes into account a user?s throughput-delay tradeoffs and cellular budget constraint. AMUSE users can optimize their bandwidth rates according to their own cost-throughput-delay tradeoff without relying on support from different apps? content servers.

 

Networked Drone Cameras for Sports Streaming: Leveraging the emerging paradigm of fog networking to coordinate a network of drones equipped with cameras, we capture and broadcast the dynamically changing scenes of interest in a sports game. We designed a system-level architecture that leverages fog networking to distribute the decision-making for control and video-streaming across the networked drones to respond at faster time scales. The application has two objectives-maximizing the coverage area and maximizing the available throughput for high-quality video streaming to servers around the field.

 

Economics of network infrastructure sharing: A new approach of combining network infrastructures as well as offloading data to WiFi is proposed to address challenges of expensive data charges and a greater volume of data traffic. As anti-trust regulations can restrict merger efforts to pool ISPs? infrastructures, such infrastructure sharing is often infeasible unless done by third-party cross-carrier operators (i.e., a virtual ISP, or vISP) by partnering with multiple infrastructure-owning ISPs. Building on the other research results that we have in this project, it becomes evident that the infrastructure sharing is feasible. We further study if it is also economically viable. We answered the following questions for different parties in the business model:  1) What are users' decision on which ISPs to subscribe to? 2) Who will partner with the vISP? 3) What are the impacts on non-partner ISPs? 4) Can the vISP make a positive profit?

 

ProCMotive: Bringing Programmability and Connectivity into Isolated Vehicles: We presented a novel reference architecture that can potentially enable rapid development of various vehicular applications while addressing shortcomings of smartphone-/Cloud-based approaches. The architecture is formed around a core component, called SmartCore, a privacy/security friendly programmable dongle that brings general-purpose computational and storage resources to the vehicle and hosts in-vehicle applications. Based on the proposed architecture, we developed an application development framework for vehicles, that we call ProCMotive. ProCMotive enables developers to build customized vehicular applications along the Cloud-to-edge continuum, i.e., different functions of an application can be distributed across SmartCore, the user?s personal devices, and the Cloud.

Virtualized Control over Fog: Interplay Between Reliability and Latency: To investigate the effects of latency and reliability on controlling linear IoT processes, we proposed an analytical framework by means of a control software located along the cloud-to-things continuum. Under this framework, the min-cost performance of virtualized control services is obtained. We derive the structure of optimum virtual controllers by considering reliability and latency (both communication and computation) characteristics of the fog endpoint which will execute the controller application.
